title: Increase delay for "editor.inlineSuggest.minShowDelay"
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

As of version **0.31** from **2025-09-10** we can now use `editor.inlineSuggest.minShowDelay` to specify a delay before Copilot kicks in, however there is a hard limit of 15 seconds, while it's already a nice feature I would love it to be increased.

Finally it could be nice to set this setting on per-file basis, for example when working on a `.yaml` or `.md ` file I am more inclined for the AI to help me where my main programming langage would have a higher delay increase.

Thanks again.

title: Group editor tabs by workspace folder in multi-root workspaces

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-tabs
labels.description: VS Code editor tab issues

labels.name: workbench-multiroot
labels.description: Multi-root (multiple folders) issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
  <!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
  <!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

  <!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

  ## Summary
  Add the ability to automatically group editor tabs by their workspace folder in multi-root workspaces.

  ## Description
  When working with multi-root workspaces, it would be extremely helpful to have tabs automatically grouped by their
  respective workspace folder. This would provide better visual organization and make it easier to navigate between files
  from different projects within the same workspace.

  ## Use Case
  When working with monorepos or related projects in a multi-root workspace, developers often have many tabs open from
  different folders. Currently, all tabs are mixed together in a single tab bar, making it difficult to:
  - Quickly identify which project/folder a file belongs to
  - Keep mental context when switching between different parts of the workspace
  - Organize work when dealing with similar file names across different folders

  Example scenario: In a monorepo with `API/`, `frontend/`, and `docs/` folders, having 20+ open tabs becomes chaotic when
  files from all folders are intermixed.

  ## Current Workaround
  Currently, developers must:
  - Manually use "Split Editor" to create separate editor groups
  - Manually drag tabs to organize them
  - Use the Explorer panel to check which folder a file belongs to
  - Rely on the full path shown in tooltips

  ## Proposed Solution
  1. **Automatic grouping option**: Add a setting like `"workbench.editor.groupTabsByWorkspaceFolder": true`

  2. **Visual implementation**:
     - Each workspace folder gets its own tab group/section
     - Folder name displayed as a header above each group
     - Visual separator between groups (line, spacing, or background color)
     - Option to collapse/expand tab groups

  3. **Behavior**:
     - When opening a file, it automatically appears in the correct folder's tab group
     - Dragging tabs between groups still possible for manual organization
     - Context menu option: "Move to folder group"

  ## Mockup Example
  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
  │ 📁 API                                          │
  │ [server.ts] [routes.ts] [config.json]          │
  ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
  │ 📁 frontend                                     │
  │ [App.tsx] [index.css] [components.tsx]         │
  ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
  │ 📁 docs                                         │
  │ [README.md] [API.md]                           │
  └─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

  ## Additional Context
  - Similar features exist in other IDEs like JetBrains IDEs with their "Tab Groups" feature
  - This would be especially valuable for monorepo development, which is increasingly common
  - Could integrate well with the existing "Workbench > Editor: Tab Sizing" options
  - Related to workspace organization features like the multi-root workspace explorer

  ## Alternative Approaches Considered
  - Color-coding tabs by workspace folder (less organized but simpler)
  - Adding workspace folder badges/icons to each tab
  - Showing folder path in tab title (too verbose)

  ## Impact
  This feature would significantly improve the developer experience for anyone working with:
  - Monorepos
  - Multi-root workspaces
  - Projects with multiple related codebases
  - Microservices architectures

title: Support negative search filters in the Extensions view
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently it is [already possible](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/configure/extensions/extension-marketplace#_extensions-view-filters) to filter the entries in the extension view using various filters, such as `@installed`, `@builtin`, etc.

However, there doesn't seem to be a way to specify a negative filter, e.g `@installed not:@category:"themes"`, to exclude rather than include a given set of extensions.

The request is therefore to allow a syntax for negative filters, with a prefix like `-`, `!` or `not:`.

Note: for completeness, doing this might mean setting up an alias for existing mutually exclusive filters — specifically, either `@disabled` → `not:@enabled` or `@enabled` → `not:@disabled`.

title: Add Option to Hide Explorer Twisties for All Expandable Files
body: Issue Type: Feature Request VS Code Version: [1.104.1] OS Version: [Windows 11] Description The Explorer currently displays twistie arrows for all expandable items—folders and files with nested content (e.g., package.json, vite.config.js)—shifting content right and creating a cluttered layout. While icon themes allow hiding arrows for folders, there’s no option to hide them for all expandable files, which is needed for a cleaner interface. Proposed Solution Add a setting to provide the option to hide twisties for all expandable files. The settiong should allows us to toggle between hide and show file arrows Use Case Gives users the flexibility to remove arrows from nesting files (e.g., package.json, vite.config.js) for better readability and a streamlined view, without losing folder navigation cues when desired. FROM: SHOULD LOOK LIKE THIS:

title: Implement right-arrow key behavior in Command Palette

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: quick-open
labels.description: Quick-open issues (search, commands)

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In the Quick Open menu (Ctrl+P), I can open multiple files quickly by pressing right-arrow key: it doesn't close the menu.
I think this would be cool if it applied to Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P) too: my use case is that i want to quickly start multiple tasks.

title: Allow screen recording for context (video files)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

It would be great if we could record our screen and voice and add that to copilot agent context.

Much easier to explain what we are trying to do than attach images and write text instructions (or record voice).

If you can follow the mouse pointer then even better, or allow us to highlight some part with some marker, like draw something on the screen.

title: chat doesn't take args in terminal profile
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.2
- VS Code Version: 1.104.1
- OS Version: win11 pro workstation 10.0.26100 N/A build 26100
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):agent
- Selected model (e.g. any):
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1.set terminal:
    "terminal.integrated.profiles.windows": {
        "git-bash": {
            "overrideName": true,
            "path": [
                "C:/scoop/apps/git/current/usr/bin/bash.exe"
            ],
            "args": [
                "--login",
                "-i"
            ]
        },
    },
    "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.windows": "git-bash",

2.in agent mode, ask to execute "uname -a"
sam@CJSCOPE-6NCLAPA UCRT64 ~
$ uname -a
bash: uname: command not found

my transition solution:
git-bash can switch from "C:/scoop/apps/git/current/usr/bin/bash.exe" to the wrapper "C:/scoop/apps/git/current/bin/bash.exe", but msys2 (i'm using UCRT64) cannot.

labels.description: Color theme issues

body:
It would be fantastic if VS Code would switch themes automatically by default. We could do some migration:

- If a user doesn't have a theme configured, or they have any of the `Light*` or `Dark*` themes configured, we would automatically onboard them to `autoDetectColorScheme: true`.
- Otherwise, we'd set `autoDetectColorScheme: false`.

title: New setting github.copilot.chat.EnableAlternateGptPrompt is overwritten by setting github.copilot.chat.Gpt5AlternatePrompt for GPT-5 family models
body:
The vscode-copilot-chat team is doing a lot of experimental work with alternate prompts for agents recently, which is great.

But it seems that one of the main features I was looking forward to in the new release (github.copilot.chat.EnableAlternateGptPrompt implemented in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/467) is not available for GPT-5 family models because the setting is overwritten by another new setting (github.copilot.chat.Gpt5AlternatePrompt). See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/f2d8f317d77cb923838dad823b6db99640f057d9/src/extension/prompts/node/agent/agentPrompt.tsx#L164 for the source of the issue.

Hoping this can be resolved.

title: Allow customizing "Sync Changes" behavior to exclude git push

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: scm
labels.description: General SCM compound issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Type: Feature Request In the current Git integration in VS Code, the "Sync Changes" button performs both git pull and git push in sequence. This behavior is problematic in workflows where pushing should be a deliberate and manual action. ### Feature Request: Add a setting or configuration option to customize the behavior of "Sync Changes", allowing users to choose whether it: - Executes pull only - Executes fetch + pull - Executes pull + push (default) ### Why this matters: Automatically pushing local commits can lead to unintended consequences, especially in collaborative or protected branches. Many developers prefer to review changes after pulling before deciding to push. ### Workaround limitations: While manual use of Pull and Fetch is possible, the "Sync Changes" button is prominently placed and often used out of habit. A configurable behavior would improve safety and flexibility. Thank you for considering this enhancement! VS Code version: Code 1.100.0 (19e0f9e681ecb8e5c09d8784acaa601316ca4571, 2025-05-07T12:48:53.763Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 5.15.0-153-generic Remote OS version: Linux x64 5.15.0-153-generic Remote OS version: Linux x64 5.15.0-153-generic

title: Feature Request: Add default UI section for user-specified shell and working directory settings for Copilot
body:
When working in large monorepos, GitHub Copilot often executes commands from the root directory by default, then retries from the correct subdirectory. Also, users of non-bash shells (e.g., fish) face command generation issues due to Copilot initially generating bash commands and then adjusting.

To improve this experience, I request a dedicated, default settings section in the GitHub Copilot UI where users can specify:

- Their preferred shell for command execution  
- The default working directory for Copilot commands  
- And, more that would lead to DX improvements and save LLM requests.

As a temporary workaround, it would be helpful if Copilot respected these user-specified preferences in its internal instructions, so it can run commands correctly on the first attempt.

### Reproduction steps

1. Open a monorepo workspace with nested subdirectories in VSCode.  
2. Enable GitHub Copilot.  
3. Generate shell commands targeting a subdirectory (providing subdirectory as context specifically using `#` command) other than the workspace root.  
4. Copilot creates a new shell that starts from the root. It runs from the root first, fails, and then retries correctly.  
5. Change VSCode shell to fish or other non-bash shell.  
6. Generate shell commands and notice initial failure followed by auto-adjusting commands for fish.

***

**Expected behavior:**  
- A default UI section for setting shell and working directory preferences for Copilot. 
- Copilot respects these preferences immediately when generating and running commands to avoid initial errors or retries.

## Recomemndations
- Additionally, I think these settings might be too specific. Instead, if users can force Copilot to use a specific terminal number/name in VSCode for it to run its commands in, then it would solve both problems and future issues, and no defaults would be needed. 
- Copilot's choice to start a new terminal causes a few problems as mentioned by a fellow user. 

> where it always starts a new shell, which then misses the environment variables that I was using. It’s a nice security boundary, of course, but suboptimal.

**Additional context:**  
This would streamline workflows for monorepo development and shell customization, greatly improving user experience.

title: Feature request: Help to create tool sets for Copilot Agent
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

One of the recent releases added toolsets: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/chat/chat-agent-mode#_define-tool-sets

However, we have a challenge to create new toolsets: there is no simple way to get a list of all tools, so it becomes very tedious to identify tools in the tool picker, copy their names, and re-compose the sets we want.

We propose two features:
1. An easy way to get a list of all available tools and their descriptions.
2. A function to save the current tool selection as a new tool set.

Caveat: Maybe toolset names need to be namespaced. I think today they are not. see also #267811

title: Using the Kill Terminal icon fails to end running processes
body:
Type: Bug ```markdown # Issue: Using the Kill Terminal Icon Fails to End Running Processes ## Description When running the `npm run dev` command for the `sports-service` project, the terminal output indicates that the development server is started using `nodemon` to watch the `src/server.js` file. However, clicking the **Kill Terminal** icon in the IDE (e.g., VS Code) does not properly terminate the running processes, including the `nodemon` process and its child process (`node src/server.js`). This leaves processes running in the background, potentially causing port conflicts or resource usage issues. ### Terminal Output The following is the terminal output when running `npm run dev`: ``` > sports-service@1.0.0 dev > nodemon src/server.js [nodemon] 3.1.10 [nodemon] reading config .\nodemon.json [nodemon] to restart at any time, enter `rs` [nodemon] or send SIGHUP to 11256 to restart [nodemon] ignoring: .\node_modules/**/* .\.git/**/* .\tests/**/* .\scripts/**/* .\load-test-reports/**/* *.test.js *.spec.js [nodemon] watching path(s): src\**\* [nodemon] watching extensions: js,json [nodemon] starting `node src/server.js src/server.js` [nodemon] spawning [nodemon] child pid: 15292 [nodemon] watching 130 files {"level":30,"time":"2025-09-23T04:07:18.563Z","msg":"Γ£à S3 client configured successfully."} [dotenv@17.2.2] injecting env (0) from .env -- tip: 📡 version env with Radar: https://dotenvx.com/radar {"level":30,"time":"2025-09-23T04:07:18.785Z","msg":"≡ƒöä Connecting services..."} {"level":30,"time":"2025-09-23T04:07:19.438Z","msg":"Γ£à All services connected"} {"level":30,"time":"2025-09-23T04:07:19.441Z","msg":"Γ£à Server running on port 5000"} ``` ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open the project in an IDE (e.g., VS Code). 2. Run `npm run dev` in the terminal to start the development server. 3. Observe that the server starts successfully, with `nodemon` watching the specified files and the server running on port 5000. 4. Click the **Kill Terminal** icon (trash can icon) in the IDE's terminal panel. 5. Check running processes (e.g., using `ps aux` on Linux/macOS or Task Manager on Windows) to confirm that `nodemon` and/or `node` processes are still active. ### Expected Behavior - Clicking the **Kill Terminal** icon should terminate all processes started by `npm run dev`, including the `nodemon` process (PID: 11256) and its child `node` process (PID: 15292). - No processes related to the `sports-service` project should remain active after killing the terminal. ### Actual Behavior - The **Kill Terminal** icon closes the terminal panel but does not terminate the `nodemon` or `node` processes. - The server continues running in the background, and port 5000 remains occupied, which can cause conflicts when restarting the server. ## Environment - **Node.js Version**: [Specify your Node.js version, e.g., v20.x.x] - **Nodemon Version**: 3.1.10 (as shown in the output) - **Operating System**: [Specify your OS, e.g., Windows 10, macOS Ventura, Ubuntu 22.04] - **IDE**: [Specify your IDE, e.g., VS Code 1.93.1] - **Project**: `sports-service@1.0.0` ## Additional Context - The `nodemon` configuration is read from `.\nodemon.json`. - The server is running on port 5000, as indicated in the log. - The `dotenv` package (version 17.2.2) is used to inject environment variables from a `.env` file. - The issue may be related to how `nodemon` spawns child processes or how the IDE's terminal handles process termination. ## Suggested Fix Please investigate why the **Kill Terminal** icon fails to terminate the `nodemon` and `node` processes. Potential solutions may include: 1. Ensuring the IDE sends the appropriate termination signals (e.g., `SIGTERM` or `SIGKILL`) to all child processes. 2. Modifying the `nodemon` configuration to handle termination signals more gracefully. 3. Adding a custom script or configuration to explicitly clean up processes when the terminal is killed. 4. Checking for known issues with the IDE's terminal or `nodemon` version 3.1.10. ### Workaround As a temporary workaround, users can manually terminate the processes by: 1. Running `kill -9 11256` (for the `nodemon` process) and `kill -9 15292` (for the `node` child process) on Linux/macOS. 2. Using Task Manager on Windows to end the `node.exe` processes. 3. Alternatively, restarting the IDE or system may clear the processes, but this is not ideal. ## Related Issues - Check if there are similar issues reported in the `nodemon` GitHub repository: [nodemon issues](https://github.com/remy/nodemon/issues). - Check for known bugs in the IDE's terminal implementation (e.g., VS Code issues: [VS Code issues](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues)). ## Labels - Bug - Terminal - Nodemon - Process Management ``` VS Code version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes: Unsupported

title: Claude Models Trigger Network Errors in Copilot Chat
body:
Type: Bug When using any Claude model within Copilot Chat, the chat request fails due to a network error. This issue is specific to Claude models and does not occur with other models. Error Details: Error Message: Sorry, there was a network error. Please try again later. Request id: 16a09855-0f9e-48e6-a33d-4443ff3a6c8e Reason: Please check your firewall rules and network connection then try again. Error Code: net::ERR_CONNECTION_CLOSED Steps to Reproduce: Open Copilot Chat. Select any Claude model (e.g., Claude-4 etc.). Attempt to send a chat request. Observe the network error and failure to complete the request. Expected Behavior: The chat request should complete successfully without network errors, similar to other models. Additional Context: The issue is consistent and reproducible. No network or firewall changes have been made on the user’s end. Other models (e.g., GPT-5, etc.) work without issues. title: Github copilot bugging
body:
Type: Bug It constantly keeps files for context over multiple messages like if I add 2 files for context in the first message and 2 different files for context in the second message, the second message will end up with 4 files for context and will constantly keep adding and slow down the response. title: Implement AI search success tracking telemetry for user interaction analytics
body:
Adds comprehensive telemetry tracking to measure AI search effectiveness and user engagement patterns in VS Code's search functionality.

## Overview

This PR implements a telemetry framework that tracks how users interact with AI search results compared to traditional text search, providing data-driven insights for improving the AI search experience.

## Key Features

### 📊 **Search Session Tracking**
- **Session Management**: New `SearchSessionTracker` class manages search session lifecycle and metrics
- **Query Patterns**: Tracks search behavior including query count, AI usage, and trigger methods
- **Success Measurement**: Determines session success based on user interaction with results

### 🎯 **Result Interaction Analytics**
- **Click Tracking**: Enhanced `onFocus()` method captures when users click on search results
- **AI vs Text Classification**: Differentiates between AI and traditional search results using `isAIContributed` property
- **Performance Metrics**: Measures time-to-click, result ranking, and engagement patterns

### 📈 **Telemetry Events**

**`aiSearchResultClick`** - Fired when users interact with search results:
```typescript
{
  resultType: 'ai' | 'text',           // Source of the result
  resultRank: number,                  // Position in results list (1-based)
  queryLength: number,                 // Length of search query
  searchTriggerType: 'auto' | 'manual' | 'runOnEmpty',
  timeToClick: number,                 // Milliseconds from search completion
  totalAIResults: number,              // Total AI results available
  totalTextResults: number             // Total text results available
}
```

**`searchSessionComplete`** - Fired when search sessions end:
```typescript
{
  sessionDuration: number,             // Total session time in milliseconds
  queryCount: number,                  // Number of queries in session
  aiSearchTriggered: boolean,          // Whether AI search was used
  aiResultsUsed: boolean,              // Whether user clicked AI results
  sessionSuccessful: boolean,          // Whether session ended with file opened
  finalResultType: 'ai' | 'text' | 'none'
}
```

### 🔒 **Privacy & Compliance**
- All telemetry follows VS Code's GDPR guidelines with `SystemMetaData` classification
- No personal information or file content is collected
- Purpose-driven data collection for `FeatureInsight` and `PerformanceAndHealth`
- Graceful error handling ensures telemetry never impacts user experience

## Integration Points

The implementation hooks into existing search infrastructure:
- **Search Triggers**: `onQueryTriggered()`, `requestAIResults()` 
- **Completion Tracking**: `onSearchComplete()`
- **Result Interaction**: Enhanced `onFocus()` method
- **Lifecycle Management**: View disposal and session cleanup

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests in `searchTelemetry.test.ts` covering:
- Session lifecycle management
- Query and result tracking
- Telemetry event generation
- Edge cases and error conditions

## Benefits

This telemetry enables data-driven improvements to AI search:
- **Engagement Analysis**: Compare AI vs text search effectiveness
- **UX Optimization**: Identify successful interaction patterns
- **Feature Development**: Guide future AI search enhancements
- **Performance Monitoring**: Track search success rates and user satisfaction

The implementation is lightweight, privacy-compliant, and provides actionable insights without impacting search performance or user experience.

title: Don't auto-open files while the agent is generating suggestions

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

body:
As we scale our use of agent mode and agent mode's ability to make edits to many files, we should remove the behavior that auto-opens files in the editor while the agent is making changes. 

Users can still 'watch' these changes by opening the file from the working set area, but if they're multi-tasking or spinning off multiple long-running tasks they can focus on something in the editor and not be interrupted by the agent opening a file unexpectedly.

title: Hide the 'Keep' 'Undo' and diff buttons on the working set until changes are complete

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

body: Problem: Today while code suggestions are generating we show the 'keep' and 'undo' buttons as disabled. These items are non-interactive and add more visual noise to the UI. Suggestion: Hide the 'keep', 'undo', and diff buttons while the code is generating, then show when the file changes are ready for review. This will bring further attention to that area and make it more clear what the current state is (as opposed to when folks are watching the chat or checking in while it's in progress). Furthermore, if there are tool calls or confirmations that utilize a primary button while the agent mode is in progress, then focus can remain on that as the action to focus on.
